Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2016 08:22PM - edited Feb 12, 2016 08:24PM by LisaAlissa Hi Dad'sLilRed! I'm glad you've found a PCP and now have insurance. Sounds like you have a careful PCP, who's sending you through the standard well-woman checks with your findings. First of all, stop spending time with that "quack, Dr. Google!" Half the time the details are wrong, outdated or simply don't apply to you!) Just go with the flow. Your odds (of not having cancer) remain pretty good. Here's a flow chart showing how women go through the screening process from the Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process:  On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. Your doc found "something" that they want to take a closer look at during your routine screening mammogram, so they asked you to come back for additional imaging (a diagnostic workup). Unfortunately, you didn't "fall out" of the screen at that point. Of the people who are sent on to biopsy (your category) 80% will be told their biopsy doesn't show cancer. I had the sort of biopsy you will. It's weird. Laying on a table that's raised up above the medical professionals, with your breast hanging down through a hole in the table. But they give you painkiller (a numbing injection) before the biopsy. Then it's startling (and loud) when they use the biopsy "gun" to get the sample or samples. But it shouldn't hurt. If it does, tell them than you need more numbing medicine. Afterwards, they checked (with another mammogram) to see if they got what they wanted. For me, they repositioned and took another sample. (I could elect to have a warm blanket and volunteer who would pat my shoulder during the procedure. And I did--both! Afterwards, they gave me two cold gel paks that I could alternate putting in my bra. It was all I needed to help with pain afterwards.) In the meantime, call your doc's scheduler and tell them you're worried and would like someone to talk you through what you can expect. I know it's easy to worry, but really. Try not to borrow trouble that isn't yours yet. Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2015 03:55PM - edited Nov 3, 2015 03:56PM by LisaAlissa Unofficial pre-medicating (unofficially) can turn out to be a very, very bad idea. The effect on bleeding. The combination with the anaesthetic used by the biopsy team. All things you don't/can't know. Does the biopsy team know about your pain meds? Have you specifically mentioned the meds to them? If not, you should. If they do biopsies regularly, they are likely to be accustomed to doing biopsies on patients on pain meds. You just need them to understand that you are in that population, even though you don't have a current cancer diagnosis. Do you have a pain doc? He/she may well have ideas (or even want to interface with whoever is doing the biopsy). What I would suggest is call the biopsy center and ask to speak to the pain management doc. Give them all the information you can about your pain meds,, tell them about your concerns and ask about anxiety pre-meds or if there are other things they'd suggest. Separately (and this may sound silly), but the breast center that did my core needle biopsy put a warm blanket over me and had a volunteer who (with my consent) rubbed my back/patted my shoulder and held my (other) hand during the procedure. Very comforting. And I had someone's hand that I could squeeze if I needed to. Best wishes with your biopsy (for best pain control & results!) LisaAlissa

Eighty percent of all breast biopsy results (all ages, etc.) are benign.  So 20% of all breast biopsies have postive (bad) results.  Your risk would be even less than 20% because of your age. If you can, get out of your house and do something to get your mind off of this. The results won't change because you do (or don't) worry.  Think about holiday shopping, decorating, a movie or whatever.   Best wishes for a wonderful weekend. (And if you have to deal with a "bad" Monday...it won't be any worse--or better--because you didn't spend the weekend worrying...and you can come back here then and we'll help.) Just some thoughts. Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 01:39PM LisaAlissa wrote: Caren, you said that "If your mom tested negative for the brca genes, YOU CANNOT HAVE THE GENES ! " Unfortunately, that's not exactly right.  The mutation can come from either side of the family, so knowing that her mother tested negative gives her significantly more comfort than all of those in the world who haven't had a parent tested, but doesn't assure her that she didn't inherit the gene mutation from her father. Usually we don't focus on the "other side" of the family, since the family history that led to a concern that there could be a genetic mutation of the BRCA gene is usually on only one side of the family.  But if the children of a person who tested negative are "lucky" enough to have bad history (or no history) on the other side of the family, a genetic counselor may recommend testing for the children even though a parent has already tested negative. When in doubt, check with a genetic counselor. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 11:12AM LisaAlissa wrote: I remember warm blankets (very calming) and a volunteer whose job was to pat/rub my back/shoulder.  Since you're worried about it, you might call ahead to the center where you'll have your biopsy done, and ask about warm blankets and calming hands.  (And if you can bring your own, if they don't provide them.) And BeingHopeful1 is exactly right.  It definitely didn't take 2-3 hours.  I don't think it took over an hour, and they had to reposition and start over on mine, as when they did the (first) post-biopsy mammogram to confirm proper biopsy, they discovered they had to re-do! So I ended up w/ two 1/8" biopsy scars right next to each other...sort of like a quotation mark. Your task in all of this is to breathe and deliberately relax your muscles (sort of like the ending pose in a yoga session).  Very meditative. A sedative/anti-anxiety med doesn't need to be administered via IV to be effective.  Call the office of the doc who ordered the biopsy and ask to talk w/ his nurse.  Tell her about your concerns and ask for a pre-biopsy sedative/anti-anxiety med.  It's very common. (Where I had my biopsy, they asked on admission if you've had one, so they can make sure you won't be driving afterwards if you did.)  Combined w/ a warm blanket, etc. I don't think you'll have the trouble you are thinking you will.  You will, however, need a driver to take you home after.    You can do this.   LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2017 10:23PM LisaAlissa wrote: If they identify something that needs to be biopsied, it is often the surgeon who reviews the imaging (and imaging reports) and orders (or sometimes does) the biopsy. The surgeon is the specialist who usually consults after the imaging is done. So you'll talk with the surgeon--probably about getting a biopsy, but maybe about enhanced screening. You won't know until you talk with the surgeon. You do want to ask for copies of all of the imaging reports, as well as CDs of the actual imaging itself. Very useful, especially if you move, or the imaging center you used closes, or has a fire or whatever. What happens after that depends on what the biopsy results are. Approximately 80% of biopsies are NOT BC! If they are negative (benign, B9--not BC), then the surgeon may suggest returning to normal screening, or suggest that you be screened more frequently. Or whatever. If it's BC, then we'll help you sort out what next. Traditionally, the next step is surgery. But for certain kinds of BC, increasingly you may want to talk with a medical oncologist before any further surgery. But all of that is getting way ahead of yourself. Have your MRI, see the surgeon. Take someone with you or ask if you can record your consultation with the surgeon. It can be hard to take in all that a surgeon will tell you. So nice to be able to listen again or to talk with someone who was with you. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2016 01:43PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Wen! Yes, many (most?) of us felt that way...we felt perfectly healthy and then they told us they weren't--it definitely didn't feel real. We didn't start to feel "ill" until we were being treated. And then it's the treatments (surgery, radiation, chemo, hormonals, etc.) that make us feel ill. Just don't let what I call the "natural denial" keep you from showing up (for your treatments, appointments, etc.). I know you got results, and have an appointment with a surgeon, but do you have your pathology report? Or do you get that when you meet with the surgeon? You're going to want to start a filing system to keep all of your papers. Procedure reports, pathology reports, blood tests, imaging reports (as well as copies of the imaging studies themselves), bills, explanations of benefits, requests for pre-approvals. There's tons of paper generated in connection with a BC diagnosis, and you'll want to try to get on top of it from the beginning. It can also be useful when you visit a new doc, to be able to hand over copies of the things they need (when the things that were supposed to be forwarded haven't gotten there ::roll eyes::). Often, surgeons want to immediately schedule surgery. But remember that you do have time. You don't have to make a decision on the spot...and you may want a second opinion. Or want to meet with a medical oncologist (and possibly a radiation oncologist) before surgery. Depending on your specific diagnosis, medical oncologists are sometimes prescribing chemo before surgery to shrink the tumor to be excised. It's very hard to hear someone discussing your cancer and be able to take it all in and remember it. Consider taking a "second set of ears" with you--someone who can take notes and help you make sure you get all the questions on your list addressed. It can also be good to ask if you can record the consultation. Re-listening to it later can be very helpful. Please keep coming back--and hang in there! LisaAlissa

Posts.Title: Should I have asked more questions? slight indent on left breast Worried1234 LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2016 12:56PM LisaAlissa wrote: "Hello ladies! I come to you for advice. Earlier this month I discovered a very slight, shaped indentation on the bottom inside of my left breast. It can only be seen when I raise my arms. I found it while combing my hair after a shower and could not remember ever seeing it before. I wouldn't call a dimple per se, more of a very shallow divot. In addition to slight indent, I also have an ache-y type of pain in my breast, but I can't tell if that is because I have been touching it for the past month relentlessly or because something is not right. Of course, I look it up and Dr. Google sends me into an anxiety spiral! I went to my GP who could not feel any type of lump but referred me for an ultrasound and to see a breast surgeon. Nothing was found on the ultrasound and the breast surgeon did not seem to be worried about it. My question: should I have asked any follow up questions to the breast surgeon after the exam? In my relief, I totally forgot to ask any questions. She told me that it could just be the natural contour of my breast and that I had simply never noticed it before. The ultrasound did show that I had a "normal fibroglandular pattern." A little bit about me: I am not 30 yet and I have had two paternal aunts who have been diagnosed with breast cancer (both before the age of 50, one in her mid 30s). Any advice would be greatly appreciated. She told me that it could just be the natural contour of my breast and that I had simply never noticed it before. " Maybe. But maybe not. Take some pictures of what the "slight shaped indentation" looks like now and from time to time--and date the pictures. Take them at regular intervals. Maybe start with once a week if you're feeling nervous. If you're not feeling nervous or if you're not seeing changes at weekly intervals, you can stretch it out to monthly. Your pictures should also have something in them for scale. Like a small bandaid dot, or small sticker. Something you can apply before you take the picture, and that is easy to get more of so that you can continue to use the same thing to allow a comparison between pictures. If there are changes, they might well be so gradual that you don't realize that there are changes for quite some time. Dated pictures will let you identify any changes and share them with your medical practitioner. Since it can only be seen when you raise your arms, you might have trouble taking pictures--or maybe that will be perfect for you to take pictures? Or maybe you need a tripod and a timer? Or a helper to be the photographer. You'll have to experiment. For instance, I'd put a scarf or bandeu top over the nipples so that the pictures are "family friendly" unless nipples are relevant to the issue involved. But you should decide for yourself what is and isn't needed in photos to document the indentation. So to get to the question I would have asked the BS...can I call for an appointment if there are changes? HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 04:02AM - edited Mar 14, 2016 04:03AM by LisaAlissa Hi apotter77! When you have concerns about your breasts, see your primary care provider, and tell them what you've told us, as well as anything else you've noticed or have concerns about. Write it all down (a list, questions or whatever) and take it with you. That way your medical practitioner can address all of your concerns. I can't say what this all might mean (I'm not a medical practitioner), but there are usually lots and lots of things that aren't cancer that can cause various symptoms. So try not to stress. As long as you are working with your medical practitioner to follow this up, you're doing what a well-woman should do when faced with breast-related symptoms. What you need to know is what caused/is causing the things that concern you. You might be referred to a breast center, or you might be referred for testing of some sort, you might be referred to a specialist of some sort, or you may be asked to follow some sort of treatment regime to see if it affects the symptoms you've seen. Any of them can be a suitable approach. The question you want to make sure you have the answer to when you leave the medical office is what should happen next? When should it happen? And when should you call back if whatever-it-is hasn't happened. And just keep pursuing answers until you (and your medical practitioners) are satisfied. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2015 07:11PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Briesmom! Nope. Don't try to read meaning into the "extended time." It could be anything. For example, maybe the lab is open, but many of the people there had vacation time they needed to take (so the lab was short-staffed)?. Maybe they had urgent in-hospital analyses to make (and since BC can have been growing for 6-10 years before found, a few extra days didn't seem like it would matter, so yours got pushed to the bottom of the pile). Maybe the typist who puts the results together did other tests first? Maybe yours was so clearly benign that they got reports out to people who had "real trouble" first? (and I could speculate on and on...) There's simply no way to know. Since the results were supposed to be in today, see if they're where you expect them to show up by mid-morning tomorrow. Then if you can't stand it, start calling, with your Dr's office first. If they don't have it, ask them if they know what happened and if they've been given a new ETA. If not, ask them if you can call whoever was supposed to send it to them to try to find out, etc. Don't let it go, but try not to be "the pest." You want to "enlist" your doc's office personnel in your search for the missing report. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2016 02:14PM - edited Apr 17, 2016 10:19AM by LisaAlissa "Tape on wall before... that is brilliant! I'll do it this weekend! As for the exercises, I want to start as soon as possible. I really can't risk frozen shoulders! I wonder why they freeze up like that.? " I don't want to discourage anyone (and the tape is brilliant so that you know where your presurgery reach was), but you may not want to raise your arms above your shoulders for at least the first two weeks post-surgery. Surgery can cut lymph channels and you want to give them the best chance possible to reconnect & heal. That apparently only happens during the first two weeks (or so) after they are disturbed. After that, they apparently will have healed with or without reconnecting. If it's without reconnecting, you've increased your chances for lymphedema. Take a look at the lymphadema board for more information. Yes, exercise, but give your lymph system a chance to heal before you work on full ROM. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2016 11:42AM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Farnad! I'm so sorry to hear that you have to deal with this. But I'm a little confused about your description. If it's DCIS (only) it can't be more than Stage 0. I'm wondering if you've confused grade and stage? DCIS is always Stage 0, but the cancer cells will be assigned a "Grade" of 1, 2 or 3. So you might have DCIS which is Grade 2. If your cancer is Stage 2, then you must have some other sort of cancer along with the DCIS. Maybe IDC? At any rate, take a look at your pathology report and let us know...I'm guessing it's DCIS only. Which would be good news! Hang in there, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2017 09:30PM LisaAlissa wrote: Sometimes it can be helpful to ask that meds be dispensed in manufacturer-sealed packaging. That can allow you to be certain that your pharmacy is giving you what the manufacturer supplied to them. It doesn't always work (when the quantities you're prescribed don't match the way the manufacturer packages them, for example), but it's surprising how often it does work. If the number you're prescribed doesn't match the manufacturer's packaging numbers, you can often get most of the quantity in manufacturer's packaging, and the balance in pharmacy vials, which would limit the number of doses you'd need to count at the counter. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2017 02:12PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi peaceseeker50, Yeah, it is "moot." That isn't saying that it isn't of interest to you (it is--rightly--of intense interest!); just that it doesn't matter to your next step, that is, you'd need the surgical procedure now planned, whether or not it's cancer. The findings you have at this point make the need for an excisional biopsy clear to the medical professionals. (Without concluding that it is--or is not--cancer.) BTW, if you were having the same physical procedure, it would be called a "lumpectomy," if you already had a cancer diagnosis. It's called an excisional biopsy because they still don't know. And this biopsy should give them the answer. I know you want the answer now. But sometimes it's just not available based on the tests so far. BC (or screening for BC) is a step-by-step process. And there's no use trying to rush ahead. If you think that another pathologist might have seen more clearly from the tissue that was removed, you can certainly ask for a second opinion on the slides/tissue... Note that you might discover that they agree with the findings you have so far. Not really adding anything to your information, just delaying the excisional biopsy that will give you an answer. But since you'd still be having a surgical procedure if they determine that it's cancer...why bother? You'll know more when you get pathology results back from your excisional biopsy. BTW, if you're not comfortable with the surgeon who will do the excisional biopsy--that is, you think you'd choose a different breast surgeon if it were cancer, then by all means choose another now. My very best wishes to you! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2015 06:10PM LisaAlissa wrote: Nope. But I assume he's speaking based on prior experience. Here is a link to a description on BreastCancer.org describing DCIS, and how it is diagnosed. (The description sounds a lot like what you describe.) But there are no guarantees. First of all, 80% of biopsy results are not cancer (B9 or atypia). So there's no reason to think that it's cancer at all, until a pathology report comes back with that result. But any DCIS result leaves open the possibility (however remote) that there are mixed types of cells. I think he's just trying to tell you not to worry too much. Nice of him. But it sounds like he's set you to worrying. And while I'm not going to be able to persuade you not to worry, I'll say it anyway. Try not to borrow trouble that isn't yours yet. Nothing you can do (or not do), think (or not think) can have any effect on the biopsy result. (If you can't make yourself believe that, look up "magical thinking"...we all can let ourselves fall into that trap.) But the only thing worry can do is rob you of joy in the present moment. So try not to let yourself do that. Come up with your own way of redirecting your thoughts. One pattern would be: I have a good med team, I've turned this problem over to them. Nothing I can do (or not do) will affect the results. So right now I will __________________. Then fill in the blank with something you can distract yourself with. Bake cookies, see the new StarWars movie, spend time with a friend, clean the garage...whatever! HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2016 04:28PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi MoonBlue (great user name)! When the surgeons told you the "standard" way, were they talking about standard after neoadjuvent chemo? or standard when there is no neoadjuvent chemo? If you're not sure, I'd ask them...I'd also ask the MO who prescribed the neoadjuvent chemo. Removing lymph nodes, expecially as many as all of the 1st & 2nd level nodes, is no picnic (not that any of this is). You increase your chances of lymphedema and the potential loss of range of motion dramatically. You may want to post your question on the Lymphedema board to get more information there. If it's needed, it's needed, but it's not a decision to make lightly. Hopefully others with more (and better) information will be along. LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 12:36PM LisaAlissa wrote: Here are a couple of links to "correct procedure" descriptions.  The first is from a medical equipment supplier and is the "easier read" of the two: http://www.steeles.com/catalog/takingBP.html The second was published in the American Heart Association Journal in 2005: http://hyper.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/full/45/1/142 So, what can you do to avoid an artificially inflated blood pressure reading?  Here are some ideas: 1.  Arrive early for your appointment, and sit quietly/read something that will put you in a tranquil mood as you wait.  Don't drink caffeine or smoke for as long before the reading as possible. (Both can raise the reading.)  If you're rushing, your heart-rate will be elevated, again, your reading will be higher than it should be.    2.  When you wait in the exam room, don't sit on the exam table.  Instead sit on a chair and lean back (and then ask them to take your blood pressure there) if possible.  You want to be relaxed and calm.  Breathe calmly. 3.  Don't cross your legs.  Don't hold your arm up.  Ask for a pillow (there's usually one in the room), then put it in your lap, and lay your arm on it--this will put your arm at (more or less) the level typically wanted without your needing to "help."  If the person reading your blood pressure still wants to hold your arm up...let them!  Don't help.  Muscle tension (from holding your arm up, etc.) will increase your blood pressure.  4.  Close your eyes and think "meditatively" (tell your muscles to relax--like at the end of a yoga class, or while meditating).  Closing your eyes will tend to limit the conversation.  If they start to talk to you, just say that you'd prefer not to speak while they're taking your blood pressure, so that you won't interfere with their focus.   This is not the time to think about what you're want to discuss w/ your medical practitioner and his/her staff.  With any luck, you have all of those notes in writing.  For now, just breathe tension out of your body. 5.  If (after all of that) the pressure is higher than your "usual readings,"  say so, and ask them to check your BP reading again. The second reading is often lower! HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2016 03:30PM - edited Apr 8, 2016 05:19PM by LisaAlissa Hi Twaz! It sounds to me like you are moving along very, very quickly. Perhaps even too quickly. Increasingly, medical oncologists (MOs) are suggesting pre-surgery chemo (neoadjuvent chemo) to (1) shrink the tumor before surgery, and (2) to see what chemos work on your particular tumor. If you have surgery before you even consult a MO, you'll never know whether they would have suggested that course of treatment for you. You may want to get a second opinion on something. For example, the pathology...or the treatments suggested by the docs you see first. Generally, with IDC, there's time. (There are types of BC, like inflamatory breast cancer (IBC) which are a genuine medical emergency...but IDC isn't one of them.) Hang in there and come back and talk with us if you'd like to discuss what you hear. You may want to record your consultation with the surgeon, as it's hard to hear and retain info when they're talking about your cancer! On the MO appointment in May, try calling the MO office and tell them you're wondering if they would suggest chemo before surgery, and ask if there is an earlier appointment you could get. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2016 09:12PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi StacyStrong! So sorry that you're having to deal with this, but there is still a chance that it will prove to be benign (hope, hope, hope...). The BiRADs 5 means that the person who assigned the score thinks that what they have seen and heard is "highly suggestive of malignancy." Radiologists can use the BiRADs scores they assign to assess how well they are assessing the imaging studies they see. Approximately 95% of the BiRADs 5 category studies they've assessed should result in a positive biopsy if they're doing their job well. (They can use the statistical results of biopsies on their various BiRAD 4 and 5 categories to assess how their category assignments compare to those of other radiologists. However even for radiologists who are doing a good job, there should still be some biopsies of category 5 imaging studies that have a benign result upon biopsy (at least 5%). I understand "preparing for the worst," but please don't feel you have to claim a cancer until you have a pathology report that says it is cancer. Here's hoping this is just a bump in the road. But we're here if you need us! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 06:09PM LisaAlissa wrote: A couple of thoughts. Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered is a web site for women dealing with risks of hereditary cancer risks.  Since you're considering preventative strategies, you will probably find that website (and the forum there) useful as you consider your options. Genetic counseling.  As peggy_j suggested, you should probably see a genetic counselor and consider being tested for the BRCA gene (as well as anything else the counselor suggests), and discuss how various strategies (Tamoxifen, PBMX, etc.) will address your risk profile.  Depending on the analysis of your family history and gene testing, you may also be at risk for other related hereditary cancers.  And you may want to address those risks as well. Tamoxifen.  There are some people who have serious side effects from Tamoxifen, others who don't.  After you've gained an understanding of how your various risks can be addressed, if Tamoxifen if something that sounds appropriate to you and your medical team, then why not try it?  While some women have significant side effects, others don't.  You may be one of the women without significant side effects.    Prophylactic Bilateral Mastectomy ("PBMX").  Search for one of Beesie's posts (on the DCIS board) for factors to consider as you decide whether or not a PBMX is for you.  It's not an easy decision, and as you say, you'll want to gather as much information as possible before rushing into anything.  Then it will be a decision that only you can make.  Note that for insurance to cover it, they are likely to want to make sure that you've covered all of your bases (genetic testing/risk asseesments, etc.) This isn't the only surgery that is indicated for some women facing hereditary cancer risks.  As you gather information, you'll also hear suggestions that for some women, ovaries should also be removed.  You need to have your specific risks assessed.  Good luck! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 04:26PM LisaAlissa wrote: "They put a wire piece at the area they biopsied....does anyone know why they would do that?" Hi Becky! That wire piece is often referred to as a "clip"...and it is usually made of titanium, which will be visible on x-ray (and perhaps other screening techniques).  It's like a bookmark.  It's placed to mark the place the biopsy was from, so if they need to find it again, they can.   If your biopsy is benign, the clip will tell radiologists doing screening studies that this is where the biopsy was performed, and will be an "explanation" for any scar tissue there they might see in the future.  If the biopsy is not benign, and something needs to be removed, it will help a surgeon be sure that they are at the right location in your breast.  If they didn't show you the type of wire/clip they used, ask them if they can show one to you.  They are very small. HTH (and that your results are benign!) LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 07:24PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Lynn, I'm sorry that you're having to deal with this, but can you tell us a little more about what is confusing you? It sounds as if you had surgery based on a DCIS diagnosis (after a biopsy of some sort).  You decided on a mastectomy & SNB.   The during surgery review of the SNB showed a positive node. (BTW, at that point, your surgeon would have known that you also had an invasive cancer, since DCIS (by definition) isn't invasive.)  You has a partial node disection of some sort (not sure what an "axillary contenet excision" is.). Generally speaking, the treatment required for the IDC will now govern your treatment going forward (other than making sure that the DCIS is gone--which the mastectomy should have done-- the treatment required for the IDC will be sufficient to handle the DCIS diagnosis).  Going forward, consider your diagnsis to be IDC.   You'll want copies of your pathology reports and your surgery report.  One of the things you'll want to know is "do you have clean margins." Can he tell you what stage your cancer is...and can he walk through the factors that went into the staging.  And I'd ask what it means to you that your tumor is a mid-grade. We've been seing reports of research suggesting that radiation is helpful even with a mastectomy, so I'd ask whether or not you should consult with a radiation oncologist.  He should give you a referral to one. Given that you now have an IDC diagnosis, you will also need to consult with a medical oncologist.   HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 10:05PM LisaAlissa wrote: Sorry, for some reason I wrote as if I thought you were seeing your surgeon again.  (So here I am adding to the confusion, instead of helping...) There are at least three kinds of oncologists.  Medical oncologists (often just called called "oncologists"--who I expect you have an appointment with), radiation oncologists and surgical oncologists.   Many oncologists spend the first appointment providing education about your diagnosis and what it means, the treatments they suggest and why they suggest them.  I don't think you're supposed to know everything before you go.    Consider asking them if you can record the session.  If it's an education session, you might want to listen to it more than once.  If that's not possible, I hope you are taking a second set of ears with you. I suspect they'll suggest some chemo, maybe some radiation.  And possibly more imaging.   I'd probably also ask about what sort of precautions you might take against lymphedema, since you've had 12 lymph nodes removed.  If he doesn't listen to your concerns, I'd consider getting a 2nd or 3rd opinion before beginning treatment.  You deserve to be listened to, and your oncologists need to be people you are comfortable with.  It makes sense to talk to a few of them if the first one doesn't feel right to you. Hang in there (HTH),  LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2015 02:31AM LisaAlissa wrote: asarge, I'm so sorry you had to deal with such dismissive medical "professionals." Everyone deserves medical teams that take their concerns seriously! It makes it harder when you're dealing with different personnel each time. The sonographer who said it was "just from breastfeeding" clearly didn't know your history (that the lump preceded breastfeeding by a couple of years) and (depending on where your US was done, shouldn't have commented at all! It's up to the radiologist to interpret the US...not the sonographer. However I'm encouraged that your new GP wants to do a fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy. While we can't know, she may have made that call before seeing the results of the US based on your several years' history with this lump. Sometimes a FNA is selected to identify a fluid-filled cyst that they don't expect will be cancer...but hard to know why they selected a FNA in your case. But there's no reason to assume that the bad attitudes of some of your prior medical personnel means they necessarily missed something. And worry won't change the results of the FNA biopsy you're scheduled to have. Try not to borrow trouble that isn't your yet. When you get the results of the FNA biopsy you'll know considerably more about your lump than you do now. When you're tempted to worry over this, just tell yourself that you have a good doc now, they've scheduled a biopsy which should give you information and there is nothing else you should do before you get those results! Then do something that requires your concentration. Hang in there! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2017 10:44PM LisaAlissa wrote: Bo, I'm so sorry you had such a bad experience. For me, I'm willing to give someone three tries to place a needle. If they can't manage it in that amount of time, I ask for a supervisor/manager--and ask for someone else to place the needle since whoever-it-is is having trouble. Good phlebotomists and oncology nurses have all kinds of "tricks" to place needles in veins that aren't cooperating. You don't have to be a pincushion while someone practices a skill at which they are not very skilled! You'll need to make your own decision, but here's what I'd do now: Call and speak with the office manager. Tell them about the tech's "fail" with the required IV placement, and that he asked you to come back in a week. Tell them that the appointment had been originally timed for the "optimal" time in your menstrual cycle to get the best possible imaging results (see djmammo's post above). You're concerned that the delay will result in sub-optimal results. Could they confirm with their radiologist that the results will be equally good a week farther into your cycle? (If not, perhaps they could get you in sooner since the problem was theirs, if the results would otherwise be impaired by the wait?) And if your veins are too bruised to use at an earlier time, can the IV be placed elsewhere? Then ask if an experienced person will be available to place the IV when you next come back, since the tech wasn't up to the task. My very best wishes to you for a much more successful imaging session next time, HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2016 06:28PM - edited Jan 28, 2016 06:29PM by LisaAlissa Hi Kkubsky. So sorry you need to be here. Take a deep breath--you can do this. Plan to take your smart phone with you to your appointment and ask to record the consultation. It's very, very hard to listen to discussions about your cancer. And a second set of ears (another person ;-) ) can be good to have along too. There will be lots of things to think about and decisions you need to make. But you don't have to make any of the decisions tomorrow. You have time. Most breast cancer has been developing 4-10 years before it is found on screening. Weeks--even a few months won't make a difference if you're actively seeking second opinions and/or exploring your options. For example, you'll want to read some of the posts from Beesie here, who has some of the most carefully researched and written posts about DCIS and treatment options: A Layperson's Guide to DCIS And you'll want to ask your surgeon what s/he would suggest you read. For instance, Dr. Susan Love's The Breast Book (new 6th ed. came out in Sept. 2015) will have info of all sorts on breasts and breast disease--most of which won't apply to you! HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2016 01:45AM LisaAlissa wrote: I had DCIS, grade 3, with comedy necrosis. But there wasn't an invasive component. No IDC. Unless you've had a biopsy that includes mention of IDC or "invasion," there's no reason to assume that the "worst DCIS" (what I had too) means you have IDC too. They worry that DCIS can somehow become invasive. Although they're not sure how, exactly, or which DCIS will "convert." If you discover (in a post-surgery biopsy) that you have an invasive component of some sort, you'll deal with it. The thing to remember about DCIS, is that it is, by definition, not invasive. If you haven't read the post from Beesie that I linked you to earlier, I urge you to do so. Finally, take another deep breath. This is "doable," and when you have questions (or just want to talk), we're here. LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2016 04:24PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Letty, It's really, really easy to try to interpret everything you see and hear as a "sign" when you're worried. But don't let your mind "go there." You're doing all of the things you should. Reporting symptoms and then letting your medical team direct your follow-up, while making sure that you don't get "lost" in the system. And there is a screening system that medical professionals use to follow up on breast symptoms and make sure that those that need to be get followed up do get followed. And it all seems routine and work-a-day to the medical professionals. And it is--to them. But to those of us who aren't familiar with the system, it's nothing short of excruciatingly frightening. At any rate, you've perhaps seen this chart around. It's from the Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process:  but I think it's helpful. On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. Your US was part of a diagnostic workup. Your docs decided that you needed a biopsy (the only way to determine if you have cancer!). And then changed their minds about what kind of biopsy. While your doc called it a "lumpectomy," it will also probably be referred to as an "excisional biopsy" (since you haven't yet been diagnosed with BC),but the procedure is the same as a lumpectomy. My impression (based on what you said) is that your docs just decided that s/he was going to want "it" out whatever the results of the biopsy, so decided you didn't need the trauma of an "extra" biopsy procedure when the results wouldn't make any difference to your surgical treatment. I like to hear about docs who think about whether the test they're proposing will make any difference to your treatment...and then don't do "unnecessary" tests! But at any rate, you've now advanced to the "biopsy" stage of the screening process. Your newly reported symptom means that they need to "back you up" in the screening process to make sure that the new symptom is properly evaluated. I'm impressed that the girl asked you to call back if you don't hear from her. Sounds like she's had good training. And that means you can be more confident in your medical team. But it's still screening. What makes it interesting is that I think you're going to be at two separate stages of the screening process at the same time. First is the scheduled surgical biopsy (lumpectomy). Note that 80% of people who have biopsies do not have cancer. i suspect that when you talk with your team on Monday, you'll get told that you need to have a diagnostic workup related to your newly described symptom. Of those who are sent on to biopsy (your first category) 80% will be told their biopsy doesn't show cancer. All of the women who are sent on to biopsy have "something" that their docs can't be certain is "ok." And there's no reason to think you will be in the 20% who are given a diagnosis of cancer. Your second screening may well delay the surgical biopsy. (Your surgeon may want to wait and see what the second diagnostic workup means for your surgical needs. Maybe nothing. Maybe something. But regarding the second screening, 75% of the people who have a diagnostic workup are told it's "nothing." You "beat the odds"the first time around--and advanced to the biopsy stage in the screening process. But no reason to think you will this time. You're still going through well-woman screening at this point. As you work your way through the screening process, a very large majority are "tossed out" at every stage--including the stage you're at. This is part of why the medical people seem so casual about the whole thing. BTW, when reading on the BCO boards, it's easy to get a skewed version of your odds...the women who were "dropped out" of the screening process don't continue to post here. So you have the people who were unlucky enough to advance all the way through the screening process who continue to post. And there's no reason to think that you will be here for very long either.  Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process (twice!!) very, very soon! LisaAlissa

This is from the Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process:  On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. You didn't "fail" the first screen (you were in the 10% of people who had a Screening Mammogram, and are being sent on for a diagnostic workup/additional diagnostic mammograms/ultrasound/MRI). Try not to borrow trouble that isn't yours yet. Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 02:55PM - edited Sep 8, 2009 03:00PM by LisaAlissa Hi Kendall, If you make an appointment with an oncologist, ask the booking person if he will want to see the films.  If so, get them from the hospital records department so that he'll have them for the appointment.  You can always take them back to the hospital after the oncologist's appointment! And you may discover that the hospital (or the place you had the imaging done to begin with) may be able to make you a copy.  Or even a DVD/CD of the films. ETA:  I'm sorry to hear that the oncologists that were recommended by your primary care doc aren't on your insurance.  I'd do two things.  First, I'd confirm that they aren't on your insurance.  Lists can be "stale" and websites sometimes aren't updated as promptly as we might wish.  Call your insurer and see.  Also call the Dr's office and ask if they accept your particular insurance. If it's still "no" on the ones recommended by your primary care doc, print out the list from your insurer and take it to your primary care doc and ask if she can reccomend anyone on the list!  If she can't, and she says she doesn't know some of them, ask her where you can go for a recommendation. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2016 04:14PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi sidharta! A BIRADs score is not a diagnosis. Instead, it's a shorthand way of describing what a radiologist sees. A "3" says the radiologist doesn't think a biopsy is warranted. That is, the biopsy itself is likely to do more harm than good. For example it can cause the kind of scarring that Melissa mentions that could obscure a problem later in life. But he would like to see if there are any shortterm changes that could change his/her opinion. So a repeat imaging is suggested before the regular screening would result in imaging. I've been told that since breast cancers can take years to develop, something this small/uncertain can safely wait on a re-check in a few months. Which is why the BIRADs 3 category exists. I'd suggest going with your doc's advice. HTH, LisaAlissa

With the holidays, I'm guessing that many of the pathology lab's schedules may be off..not that helps any. Mary, the part about the correlation is that the procedure report talks about how many samples they took (and maybe how large they are, etc.). The pathology report should say they got that same number of samples, then talk about them...probably individually. So they will correlate. For both of you, since you haven't heard yet, I'd call your doc's office back and ask when & how you can expect to hear the pathology report results. (This waiting from hour to hour is for the birds!--if you won't hear anything until the new year, then it would be nice to know that...). At any rate, you need to find out how their office handles this. Should you book an appointment with the doc to hear results? (when?) Will they call you? Will it be posted on the patient portal? If so, will they notify you that it's been posted? Or should you just keep checking? Tell them you want to know so that you will know when you should start calling around to find out what's happened. (BTW, this is always a good idea when you have a test or procedure. That is, to find out when the procedure reports/test results will be available and how. As in, when should you start worrying if you haven't yet heard...and therefore start making calls & visits to find out what's wrong. And, further, never accept a "we'll only call if it's bad news or if you need to do something." Every office has things that "fall through the cracks" in their procedures. You never want your results to be ones that were "misplaced.") And hang in there. Once you've found out when you should "find out." Try to put your worries aside. Let yourself get distracted and focused on other things. Because there's nothing you can do (or not do) that will affect the results. LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2016 11:25PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Weneke6! Definitely still a chance that it will be benign. Changes often warrant a biopsy -- but remember that they wouldn't need a biopsy if they could tell what the change was without one. Most of the people who are asked to have a biopsy (because the person reading the imaging study see something they aren't sure about) get a benign result. Approximately 80%, in fact, get a benign result. So your chances remain excellent! Best wishes, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2015 06:16PM LisaAlissa wrote: No, you are not doomed! Until after surgery (and the receipt of the final post-surgery pathology report) you won't even know what stage you're at! (Have you been conflating Stage & Grade in your worrying? That happens sometimes.) Once you've got the surgical report and the final pathology reports they will "stage" your tumor, you'll be able to make more plans with your medical team about how best to treat your BC. Radiation? chemo? hormonals? more surgery? There are a lot of things that can be used. So. No doom. (And please try to stop the gloom...distract yourself. Make cookies for the holidays. Write journal entries. There is nothing you can do right now, so stop obsessing about it. When you find your mind going there, just say to yourself: I have a good medical team, I have a good next step scheduled, and I have done everything I can, Nothing I do (or don't do) will change anything... So let it go. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 5, 2016 07:37PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Mom22girls! So sorry you're having to deal with these concerns. I can't help with most of your questions, but on the why your "breast would go up in density when its supposed to go down during perimenopause," question, it's quite possible that there has been no change in density. The description of density is based on the opinion of the radiologist reading the mammogram. If the first radiologist thought it was 50%, then you would get the description (26-50% dense) from your earlier mammogram. If the second radiologist thought it was 51% dense, then you would get the new description (51-75% dense). It's entirely possible that there has been no change in density...or even a decrease in actual density, just a variance in how different radiologists respond to the same density in an image. The BIRADS 0 simply indicates that the new radiologist isn't done with his review...and s/he won't be until they get the older mammogram images (not the reports, the actual images). Once they have that, they'll be able to assess changes and identify any areas of concern and (hopefully) relate all of that to your other symptoms. If I were you, I'd follow up on the arrival of the earlier images and make sure that your radiologist (the one waiting for the old images to arrive in the mail) knows that you're going to see a breast specialist on Thursday and would like older images, newer images and all interpretive reports to be sent for arrival at breast specialist's office before Thursday. You will also want to get copies of older images, newer images and all interpretive reports to have in your own hands (your radiologist should be able to give you a CD or DVD with all of those on it)--and then hand carry them with you to the breast specialist's office. It's amazing how often reports, tests & images don't get to a new doc's office when they should. Make sure you get them back and keep them in your own files. HTH (and that your symptoms are resolved very soon), LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2016 12:40AM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Ktf777! I'm sorry that your screening mammogram shipped you into the diagnostic imaging process! US can see things that mammogram's can't (and vice-versa). While many women have dense breasts, that does make it harder to distinguish features on mammograms. So US is often added as a second way of viewing. My screening radiologist was involved in early research on adding US to mammograms...and I had both mammograms and US for more than 10 years before the year she identified very early BC (DCIS in my case). Interesting comment from the nurse (that you'll know "something" that day), but I'm not sure which day she was talking about. If it's the day you have US and a diagnostic mammogram, it could be that your imaging center will have the radiologist who reads the imaging speak to you immediately after the imaging session? Some imaging centers do that after diagnostic mammograms/US. If so, perhaps what you'll know is if they will (1) send you back to a normal screening schedule, (2) ask you to come back for follow-up screening in 3-6 months (to see if something they're wondering about has changed), (3) want yet-more imaging now, or (4) have identified an area they suggest be biopsied. I guess any of those would be something to know. If not (worst case, I suppose) is that they tell you when you will know something more. I know that you will worry, but do your best to distract yourself--no sense borrowing trouble that isn't yours yet. An "architectural distortion" is a description, not a diagnosis. The reason they need more imaging is that they don't know anything to tell you yet. For all you know, there was a fold in your tissue that caused a shadow they couldn't identify. They didn't have the right view (or perhaps the right imaging tech) to tell whether it was something that should be investigated with a biopsy or what. They're wondering, so are doing follow-up imaging (with more views) to try to discover what it was. (That's why the BIRADS score was "0.") So try not to "go there until/unless you get there." Hang in there (and let us know if we can help), LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 12:49AM LisaAlissa wrote: I'm sorry you're having to go through this.  Where I had mine done, they wrapped you in warmed blankets (because the room was kept cool), had a monitor turned so that I could see the images and had a volunteer available if you wanted them, whose job was to pat your back in a comforting way.  Sort of a "back to infancy" mode, it seemed to me, which made it much easier to sort of drowse my way through it. You might check w/ the center where yours will be done and see what sort of arrangements they have there.  Many would be able to arrange warmed blankets, and if they don't have a back-patter available, you could ask if you could bring your own. Separately, I'd check in w/ your IBS doc and see what sort of prep you could do to limit your gut's activity for the necessary period of time.  You really don't want to have to start all over (which they'd have to do if you needed to move in the middle).  When you have advice from IBS doc, I'd talk that over with the interventional radiologist or surgeon that will be doing your biopsies.  They may well have some ideas about how to handle your IBS limitations as well. Hope it all goes very well for you (that you biopsy's are in the 80% that are benign)!   LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2015 06:18AM LisaAlissa wrote: Jewel, I'm so sorry you're having to deal with all of this. Have you spoken with "your doc" about your new symptoms? The skin/texture changes + size changes? These are potentially alarming and might call for asap evaluation, even if you weren't already in the midst of a diagnostic process. Note that I don't know enough to really be helpful on that. But you want to add that to your list of "things" to discuss. Given the renowned specialist who's been involved in reading your imaging and doing your biopsy, am I safe assuming that you're at a large university or hospital with a breast center? The reason I'm asking is that most institutions like that will have "navigators" to help patients navigate the process. Or ombudsmen to help with problems. There is clearly a paper discrepancy. But it is possible that there is no actual discrepancy. That's what you need to find out. For example, it could be that one of the samples managed to be separated into two so that what the pathology lab received as seven might have been "taken" from you as six. (I have no idea, but that's an idea of what might have happened.) So. To your questions. 1. Start with a "navigator." Tell them you saw a discrepancy, and how can that have happened? That person will need to follow up with the various people who write reports/saw your samples. 2. Even if they use the same core needle, there are at least two things that could cause different sizes that come immediately to mind. How compressed were your breasts? Might they have taken samples in different areas where the compression was slightly different? Did the needle go to different depths in some of the core samples. Again, I don't know the answers--or even the possibilities. But it's certainly possible that there isn't anything wrong. Go in with a curious mind--you want to understand. No accusations...that just makes people defensive. And you want to enlist these people onto your "team" (if they aren't there already). 3. I haven't had those experiences. But given modern bar-coding/labeling procedures (where they slap a bar-coded label on the sample as it is packaged for the lab), it has become increasingly unlikely that there is a mislabeling error. That's something that the navigator may be able to help with. Where your biopsy was done, what is the procedure? Do they package/label specimens before they're taken away from the patient or the procedure room? Do they compare your bar-coded wrist band with the biopsy labels?All those things are intended to make mechanical errors less likely--although unfortunately, where humans are involved, nothing is impossible. 4. Do you still trust the "expert"? If so, ask him/her for suggestions on second opinion docs and on what portions of the process second opinions are required. (Given the bafflement among docs, the renowned expert might be as interested as you in having a second pathologist group take a look at your samples.) If you don't trust the "expert" is there another doc you do trust? Talk to that person about accessing another breast center group for second opinions. (BTW, consider checking in with your health insurer. They may well have some procedures you need to use to make sure second opinions are covered by your insurer.) 5. Finally, ask the navigator who you should ask to review the skin/texture changes. You are trying to avoid full-panic mode (they should appreciate that), but want to make sure that a new and potentially alarming symptom gets included in the diagnostic process. HTH (and best wishes--hope you hear that all is in order and nothing to worry about), LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2017 12:49PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi MikNik, You should ask your doc about his decision-making process, but here's what I told another woman who asked pretty much the same question: "They will always try to use the least invasive procedure that will get them the results they need. Absolutely "best" for results/information is an excisional biopsy, where they take out the entire area that is of concern. Of course, that is a big procedure (surgery) and leaves big scars (which might be disfiguring and/or make later imaging harder to interpret). One of the least invasive biopsies is a fine needle aspiration (FNA). Less painkiller required, smaller scars, etc. If it can get you the results you need, it's the best. But it often doesn't produce enough information. Somewhere in between are various core needle procedures. Generally docs try to balance the various considerations. If they can get good information from a less-invasive procedure, they'll generally try that. Sometimes they are wrong, and have to move to a more invasive biopsy." djmammo had a very helpful reply following mine. I'll ask him in a PM if he minds if I repost that reply here...or perhaps he'll choose to post it himself. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 20, 2017 05:37PM - edited May 20, 2017 05:40PM by LisaAlissa Hi Kimberly, I'm so sorry you're having to go through all of this. I think some of the confusion is a matter of terminology. While a lumpectomy and an excisional biopsy are very similar (and sometimes, for that reason, they both get called a "lumpectomy,") their purposes are quite different. A lumpectomy is a surgical procedure to remove a known cancer (and hopefully get "clean margins.") An excisional biopsy is a surgical procedure to remove some "suspicious" tissue for analysis. Based on what you've said, what you're having is an excisional biopsy. Depending on what they find, they may or may not find cancer...and if they find cancer, they may or may not need to go back and clean up the margins. I can't offer an explanation about why your surgeon chose an excisional biopsy over a core needle biopsy. Generally, the least invasive biopsy (which will accomplish the surgeon's goal) is chosen. But factors involved in choosing one over the other may involve where the "whatever-it-is" is located and whether or not it is easily accessed with a core needle. Certainly ask your surgeon why he chose an excisional biopsy over a core needle biopsy. BTW, asking if treating a potential infection first would mean that a biopsy would no longer be required seems like a reasonable question. And asking how they will address a potential infection during the course of the excisional biopsy is also a reasonable question. My very best wishes for a B9 result! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2017 04:31PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Rachel, Try not to read anything into the email. It might well be a "standard form e-mail" telling you to contact the doc who ordered the tests for the results. Remember that referrals like yours for imaging and biopsies are part of the "well-woman screening" process. And that the pathology lab who did the final cytology report is typically sent to the referring doc, who is then supposed to tell you about it. There's no reason to assume that it means anything at all. Or that the cytology/pathology report says anything different than what you've heard already. Go ahead and call your doc's office, tell them that you got the email that they should have received the cytology report and so you need to make an appointment to discuss it. They may tell you you don't need an appointment, which is fine, but you still want a copy of the cytology report for your own files. And BTW, some docs meet with patients to review results no matter what they are! (Mine does...) So. Be calm this weekend, no reason for alarm. I suspect it is simply the "system" sending out its "standard" email to you. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2017 12:52AM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Jessmh! Breast lumps are very common, and getting them checked out is exactly the thing to do (so lots of people have similar experiences!). It's one of the well-woman health care routines we all do. And as we get older we add more and more things to our routines. Just think of it as a routine part of your health care. Some things to think about: 1. You're about to begin a very standard screening process, to determine whether your lump is something to worry about or not. Most of them aren't. The standard screen looks something like this:  (The chart is from Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process.) On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. I'm not sure if the first test you'll be having fits into the "screening mammogram" (really the "first screen"--even though it's a sonogram) or the "diagnostic workup" category. You'll note that the vast majority of women at each level are not advanced to the next level of screening. 1. Genetic Testing. You didn't say how old your mother & grandmothers were when they were diagnosed with breast cancer. The reason I ask is that a "young" diagnosis (before 45 or 50) is more significant than an elderly diagnosis. If they were young diagnoses, you may want to look into genetic counselling to determine whether genetic testing would be helpful for you. That would be a good question to ask when you get the results of your imaging study. It may or may not be covered by your insurance, depending on your personal and family history. Note that you do want counselling, not just testing. There can be downsides to getting genetic testing, which the counselor will be able to help you think through. If you are determined to be "high risk," you may want to begin "standard" screening earlier than usual--and perhaps with a breast specialist. 2. No prior images. At your age, I assume you don't have prior breast imaging (so nothing that they will be able to compare your new imaging to). So it's quite likely that they will ask you to come back for additional imaging (either immediately, or in 3-6 months) and/or have additional testing. Still nothing to panic about. 3. Research? You might want to read the first 50 pages or so in Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book. Those pages discuss normal breast development and common (not BC) problems. 4. Specialists. Your OB/GYN was a good place to start in checking out your lump. A GP, internist or any other primary care provider would have been an equally good place to start. But none of them are an expert in breast issues, so getting referred for imaging is entirely normal. That your GYN wasn't particularly comforting shouldn't be taken as anything more than that s/he isn't the specialist in this area. Ideally, your referral is to someone who reads breast imaging studies all day every day. That is, a breast center. You may well get a referral to someone else as well, to discuss the imaging report. If so, that person may well be a breast surgeon. If that happens to you, it doesn't mean that it's bad news. Remember that there is a "standard" screening process that they run through when someone shows up with a lump. You're feeling panic...they view it as "routine." 5. Get the actual report & a disk with the images. Whenever you have testing, be sure to ask how you will get the results, and when they should be available. You will get a so-called "patient letter," but you also want the actual report which is sent to the doc who ordered the test. Keep track of where you've had imaging, so that you can tell docs in the future where to find copies of these images. And just in case the practice where you had imaging closes/moves/loses files, ask for a copy on disk. Then you'll be able to provide the prior images yourself if a doc needs them in the future. 5. Not likely to be BC. Finally, it is extraordinarily unlikely that a woman will develop BC at 24...not impossible, but very, very, very unlikely. But getting it checked out is the responsible thing to do! 6. Skewed impression. When reading on the BCO boards, it's easy to get a skewed version of your odds of a B9 result...the women who were "dropped out" of the screening process don't continue to post here. So you have the people who were unlucky enough to advance all the way through the screening process who continue to post. And there's no reason to think that you will be here for very long either.  Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 5, 2016 01:11AM - edited May 5, 2016 01:12AM by LisaAlissa No. There's no reason to assume that it's cancer. "Suspicious" just means that there's a "something" that they want to check out. And many people have gone through this and ended up with a "not cancer" diagnosis. You've perhaps seen this chart around. It's from the Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process:  On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. You'll notice that your calcifications were found during a routine screening mammogram, and your doctor referred you for a diagnostic workup--and then for a biopsy. Of those who are sent on to biopsy (your category) 80% will be told their biopsy doesn't show cancer. Of twenty women who are sent on for a diagnostic workup (like your ultrasound), five of them will be sent on for biopsy, but only one of those five will have a cancer diagnosis. You're still going through well-woman screening at this point. As you work your way through the screening process, a very large majority are "tossed out" at every stage--including the stage you're at. BTW, when reading on the BCO boards, it's easy to get a skewed version of your odds...the women who were "dropped out" of the diagnostic process don't continue to post here. So you have the people who were unlucky enough to advance all the way through the screening process who continue to post. And there's no reason to think that you will be here for very long either.  Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2017 08:40PM - edited Sep 7, 2017 10:41PM by LisaAlissa Hi CR769! I'm so sorry you've been having so much trouble with your breasts and have found such alarming information via Google. I would not ask the Derm for a punch biopsy tomorrow. As I read your post, you've been whirling around in circles from medical practitioner to medical practitioner, following no one's advice fully and starting over again with each new appointment. And scaring yourself to death with "Dr. Google." I think you've worked your way into a tizzy and probably made the derm expect non-compliance from you, since that's what she's seen so far... So. I think you should start your appointment with the dermatologist with an apology and a request for help. Tell her that you heard a different thing every time you saw a medical practitioner for something else. And you realize that's not how to go on...and you want to follow her advice in order to get this skin condition sorted out. Write out a chronology of what you've done on whose advice and when. Bring along the three different creams you've used on your rash (hers, the anti-fungal cream & the "expensive one). It's entirely possible that the combination of the three is what has made your rash "burn"--but the derm will need to advise you on what to do now, and if you need to "live with" the burn for a while, she may also be able to give you advice about how to soothe the burn until you get the effect she's trying for. Ask her what she'd like you to do now and tell her that you'll do what she says (and mean it!!!). Ask her when you should begin to see results. And when you should call her nurse for advice if you don't begin to see them. Promise her that you'll call her nurse if you have a new symptom or side-effect from the treatment, if some other medical practitioner suggests a different course of treatment--before you begin following that course--so that her office can coordinate with theirs. And that you'll wait to hear from her office before you make any changes or additions to her course of treatment for the rash on your breasts! Why should you apologize? Here's how what you told us looks to me (and think about it from the specialist's perspective!): Day 1: The Nurse practitioner sent you to the Derm, which makes perfect sense, as they are the specialist in the body's largest organ, the skin. Evening of Day 1: The Derm told you to: 1. Rewash all of your clothes in free & clear (did you do that?--you didn't say); 2. use hydrocortisone cream 1-2x per day. (not clear when you stopped using this...when you started the anti-fungal cream? when you started the expensive cream? sometime else?) and 3. Come back in 2 weeks (Implied that you'll follow the course of treatment prescribed by the derm until the follow-up appointment!). Day 4?: But instead of following the derm's advice, within a couple of days after your 1st derm appointment you asked another PCP (primary care provider) about your rash and let the PCP overrule the skin specialist (don't you and the PCP think a dermatologist would have recognized a fungus?--did you tell the PCP about the dermatologist & her plan for treatment and follow-up?) Your PCP has you start using an anti-fungal cream, which PCP says will clear rash in 1-2 days. (Is this when you stopped using the hydrocortizone prescribed by the derm?) It doesn't. Day 6?: So the PCP orders an expensive cream (what kind?) which you don't pick up until Day 12-ish (use for 5 days --note the timeline you describe doesn't seem to work out exactly....) Day 14 or 17? Follow-up appointment with derm. who is "pissed [you] stopped the hydrocortisone cream" (not clear when you stopped, BTW) and told you to "go back on it and see her again in two to three weeks." (My impression is that you ignored her instructions completely, except for making a follow-up appointment. Is that true?) Note, you say the rash is "not itchy so no need for hydrocortisone." So my impression is that you haven't yet followed the Derm's treatment plan--which she's told you to use twice, so far. You don't (necessarily) know all of the reasons that the Derm wanted you to use that hydrocortisone cream. Can you see why the Derm was angry at your follow-up appointment, and likely will be angry again? If you don't trust the Derm, talk with your PCP about a referral to a different derm, but in either case, you need to let a skin specialist direct the treatment for this rash. I know this is a hard pill to swallow, but you need to get a derm back on your side. She's doing what a derm (skin specialist) should do. Treating for the most likely, and then moving on to less likely causes. But you haven't let her get past the first step yet. So. Apologize, ask for her help and then promise to do as she asks. Hope your rash is cleared up very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2015 11:46PM - edited Dec 28, 2015 11:47PM by LisaAlissa Ok, first, big breath. Nothing is happening right now. And nothing you do or don't do (or think or don't think) will affect any of the results at all. You've been a brave young woman in getting all of this checked out. But you don't have to be brave for any of this. You just have to show up. I'm not impressed with your nurse. If she think anything is funny (and I can't think why she should!) she should keep it to herself. Very unprofessional. Is she your primary care provider ("PCP")? If not, I'd talk w/ your PCP and get a referral to a social worker/therapist/nurse navigator. Most hospitals or breast cancer centers will have someone whose job is to help you through the process. For example, I was alone when I went through the biopsy process. The hospital where I was seen had volunteers available (if I wanted one--and I did) whose job was to pat my shoulder and rub my back during the biopsy process. And make sure that I had a warm blanket. They will give you numbing medication before the biopsy. And you should talk with someone about the procedure and ask if you can get EMLA cream to numb the area that will get that injection. Please come back and talk to us about your concerns. We are glad to talk w/ you! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 30, 2017 03:06PM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Penny, I'm so sorry you're having to deal with all of this. For the pain, have you tried small ice packs in your bra? That helped me a lot with post-biopsy pain--more than meds. If they didn't give you a couple when they did hte biopsy, you might call and ask if you can pick up a pair (that way you can have one in the freezer while you use the other one. ;-)) Separately, you should check in with your doc if that doesn't help, or if the healing doesn't seem normal. Separately, you don't seem to be able to stop thinking about "horrible possibilities." I'd say it sounds like you might want to develop some "coping mechanisms/strategies." Mindfulness--where you learn to notice that your mind had gone off to something other than what you want to be thinking of--and how to gently redirect your thoughts, might be helpful. Training involves things like focusing on your breath, then when your mind wanders (as it will) bringing it gently back to your breath. Lots of other similar exercises. But the idea is to give you tools that you can use to manage unruly thoughts and to be "mindful" of the things you want to be thinking of. Ask your doc if she can refer you to some mindfulness training--I think they have (or at least used to have) some classes at MDAnderson. If not, there are free on-line sessions from UCLA's MIndful Awareness Research Center (MARC) "here." HTH (and my best to you!), LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 01:25PM - edited Oct 11, 2011 01:26PM by LisaAlissa Hi Cnebae48, I'm sorry you're having so much trouble.  No one here is going to tell you you're too young...last year there was a 10 year old here who needed a mastectomy because of aggressive BC.  However, statistically speaking, you are much less likely to have BC than older women.  For women up to age 20, the risk is 1 in 1,760 women or (if I've divided correctly) 1/2 of 1%.  That risk calculation is for white women...the risk is slightly less for black women (although black women who hit the "jackpot" tend to have more aggressive cancers).  Take a look at this page to review some of the risk calculations. All that said, it is normal for a young woman to have dense breasts (breasts tend to become less dense with age), which the screeners find convenient, since as you no doubt have heard, mammography doesn't work well with dense breasts.  That your lump doesn't show on ultrasound doesn't mean it's not there.  Each lump is different, and different imaging techniques work better for different lumps.  You may need an MRI or some other imaging modality for your lump to be visible. It sounds as if you're being referred to a breast surgeon, and that is exactly the right next step.  The surgeon may suggest another imaging technique, or may suggest a biopsy.  Unfortunately, you'll have to wait to see. My only concern at this point is that if you have any of the symptoms of inflamamatory breast cancer you shouldn't be waiting.  That is the one type of cancer that moves very, very quickly.  I'd suggest you change the title of your thread or post another thread, including something about being worried about IBC (perhaps "young military woman worried about possible IBC" or something like that).  There are a number of women who can help you sort through what you need to do to get diagnosed (yes or no) on IBC asap from both the military and IBC perspective. Hang in there, and let us know how you're doing! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2016 10:27AM LisaAlissa wrote: Aqua, the part about people's signatures changing? That may be a bit misleading... Generally, people come here during their diagnosis or treatment, then leave. If their biopsy is negative (80% are!) they leave and move on to the other challenges in their lives. ( Looking at the stories of the people who stay makes it look like nearly everyone who gets biopsies has cancer...and we know that's not true.) Similarly most people stay through their treatment, then leave. And while they're in treatment, they tend to post on threads related to what's going on in their treatment stage. The people who stay long term (and who are thus more likely to post in support of newcomers) tend to fall into a couple of categories. Those who stay in treatment, (or return and then stay in treatment) which would be the Stage IV people and the Lymphedema people. And those who just continue to post, like (for a very long time) Beesie. For example, I returned recently to help a friend, and saw a few threads where I thought I could be helpful, so I did), but I don't expect to stay. So the fact that you see so many Stage IV signatures shouldn't be taken as a prophecy of your own future. HTH, LisaAlissa
