Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2016 10:41PM LisaAlissa wrote: Anomie, Glad you're feeling better. Let me see if I can help even further...your odds are actually a lot better than 80%! It's 80% of biopsied lumps that are benign. But you aren't at the biopsy stage yet. Take a look at this chart from the Imaginis site, which has additional info about the screening process:  On the above diagram, note that your goal is to fail to be advanced farther "up" the diagram. Each one is a narrower group of people. Your lump wasn't found during a routine screeening mammogram, but your doctor has referred you for a diagnostic workup. So you're one step up on the chart to begin with. Of all of those who are sent on to a diagnostic workup (your category!), only 25% are sent on to a biopsy--that is, 75% people "fall out" of the screen at that point. You may be told that you need to return to your routine screening schedule...or that they would like to see you again "sooner" so that can see if "whatever-it-is" is stable. Of the 25% who are sent on to biopsy (not your category yet!) 80% will be told their biopsy doesn't show cancer. You're early in the screening process. There are at least two distinct layers of screening you'd have to get through before you could even have the possibility of a cancer diagnosis. I know it's easy to worry, but really. Try not to borrow trouble that isn't yours yet. Hope you fail to advance in the diagnostic process very, very soon! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 20, 2017 11:34AM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Angela! Usual doesn't really matter (and varies depending on where you had yours done and what their usual is)...what matters is what you should expect. If you don't have results first thing Monday morning, call the doc's office who ordered the test and ask them if they're back and if they say "not yet," when you should expect to have results. They may say "after we get the report from _____," But if they don't know when they expect it, ask if you can call _______ to find out when they expect to send it out (so that you won't be calling them repeatedly asking if it's in...). Going forward, whenever you have a test or procedure, ask them when the report/test results will be available. That way you won't have to worry about when, and you'll also know when you should call to chase them down. (When reports/results don't show up when scheduled, it sometimes means they've gotten lost in the administrative/bureaucratic processing of such reports and you have to ask people to "seek" the hidden (find the lost?).) ;-) Hope your results are in first thing Monday! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 09:44AM - edited Apr 27, 2009 09:46AM by LisaAlissa Hi Stacy! Have you seen a genetic counselor?  They will be able (once you've filled out all of the relevant information forms) to assess your risks, given your situation and discuss them with you.  Depending on your circumstances, they may reccomend genetic testing (probably for the BRCA1 & 2 genes) then a further discussion.  I understand that research has shown that many women overestimate their risks related to breast cancer.  That may be what your psychologist was responding to...  But, if the risks (as the genetic counselor evaluates them) warrants it, they will help you explore risk-reducing options that are available (which may include a PBM).   See your primary care physician about a referral to a genetic counselor (ideally at a breast cancer center).  It's possible that the genetic counselling will even be covered by your health insurance, given your family history (but each insurer has their own standards, and the genetic counselor's office should be able to check that for you). Check out the web site for FORCE (Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered) which discusses risk assessment, hereditary cancer, finding a genetic counselor and how to manage risks.  You'll find lots of good information there about assessing and managing risks of hereditary cancer.  Once you've worked your way through the process, had all of the genetic work done, you may discover that you no longer want/need a PBM.  But if the risks warrant it, and you still want a PBM, you'll be in a better position to be perceived and treated as the calm, rational woman you will be (with all of the facts/evaluation at your command), and will (likely) have medical professionals who will support your decision. Best wishes! LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2016 08:36PM LisaAlissa wrote: A good genetic counselor should be able to help you sort through your family tree and the various cancers. Generally speaking, they will ask you to put together family information for them before your appointment, so they will have a chance to study your family. Since you have an appointment, if they haven't provided forms, etc. for you to use in providing that information to you, I'd call them and ask if you should have received it. When you're laying out your family tree, you may discover that there are close relatives whose history you don't know. I found it interesting to inquire of family members for details I didn't know. But it does take some time, so if they haven't told you what information they want you to provide, you need to check with them soon. Based on their analysis of your family and the history you can provide, they may (probably?) will suggest some genetic testing. But the history and types of cancer, causes of death and other illnesses are really, really important. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 08:43AM LisaAlissa wrote: Hi Elisa! It's definitely better than 80% of those called back for additional views/studies that are benign...  Remember that about 80% of biopsies show benign results.  And certainly being called back for additional views (and US) doesn't always result in a biopsy! (I don't know what the percentages are of those called back for additional views/studies that go on to biopsy.) Try to think of it as "your Mom has a good medical team that is using current screening tech and standards to provide good preventative care." For years (at least 12) my mammograms involved additional views/ultrasounds on an almost routine basis, based on dense breasts.  For the last 4 or 5 years, they simply had me schedule both mammogram and ultrasound appointments at the same time...they simply knew they would need to be able to see more, given the denseness of my breast tissue.  None of those went on to biopsy.  (My DCIS was eventually found early by mammography...but additional views weren't even required to find it!) If your Mom's mamo was read by a new radiologist, if there was new equipment (so that the prior mamos weren't as helpful), if new studies/lit suggested follow-up for something not previously followed...all of those can lead to more follow-up studies.  My radiologist told me that over time the standard seems to be moving to more follow-up imaging, especially w/ ultrasound...and that she has been in the vanguard of that movement.  Perhaps your Mom's radiologist has "stepped up" their approach to this one?  I know it's hard, but after the first couple of years, I didn't worry about the results much more than I'd worry about the results of a pap smear (also a test for cancer, but one we dismiss as "routine"). If you can, take emtesla's advice and stay positive. HTH,  LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2016 01:32PM LisaAlissa wrote: Pokie, sometimes hearing the same thing another way helps. So here goes: A "lumpectomy" and an "excisional biopsy" both remove a lump of tissue. From the surgeon's perspective, it's the same procedure (and why he might call both of them a "lumpectomy" or a "segmental mastectomy" or whatever his favorite term is for the surgery he's performing. It's the purpose of the lump removal that differs, as well as your insurance company's view of the procedure and what are the appropriate add-ons/tests before the procedure. So. If you had had a cancer diagnosis, the lumptectomy would have been to remove the cancerous tissue. But you didn't have a diagnosis, so the purpose of your excisional biopsy is to get tissue for a pathologist to examine. And since a less invasive biopsy procedure was (apparently) not suitable for you, your surgeon will try to remove the entire lump while he's there. While you might have a sentinel node biopsy (SNB) during a lumpectomy (since you know you have cancer and they want to check the nodes), you wouldn't usually have a SNB during an excisional biopsy, since you don't know that you have cancer, and wouldn't want to run avoidable lymphedema risks. You can always come back for the SNB if you end up with a BC diagnosis. HTH, LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 03:08PM LisaAlissa wrote: Based on what you've told us (potential size), it could easily be a Stage 1 or possibly a Stage II. Take a look at this and scroll down to the descriptions of the various stages and the sizes then mention as associated with each.  You'll see what I mean: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/staging.jsp  Then take a large, slow breath and let it out very slowly, because until you see the post-surgical pathology report, anything you or we say will just be a guess. I gather you're having a wire localization before surgery, which while it isn't particularly pleasant, is at least quick.  The injections? does this mean a sentinal node biopsy?  If so, are you authorizing a axillary node disection if a sentinal node is positive?  There is new research on this, which you may want to explore: that a node disection beyond a SNB doesn't offer benefit but puts you more at risk for lymphedema. And keep talking to us about what's worrying you.  It does feel real in a way it hasn't before as you prepare for you surgery. Hang in there, LisaAlissa
